snippet.title: No Transgenic Spider-Goats At The Smithsonian? Welcome To The First Post-Natural History Museum
snippet.description: The typical natural history museum shows stuffed specimens of elephants, alligators and penguins. But you won't find a transgenic spider-goat, an oversight that Pittsburgh's Center for PostNatural History recently rectified by putting one on exhibit. The spider-goat – genetically engineered to produce high-strength spider silk in its milk – joins [...] read »

snippet.title: Inside Texas Entrepreneur Randy Best's Private Natural History Museum
snippet.description: Randy Best is a compulsive collector not just of businesses but also of ancient artifacts: "It's a remarkable connection to millions of years ago. Or maybe I never grew up." read »

snippet.title: Discovery Jumps The Shark On Shark Week... And Draws Stellar Ratings
snippet.description: Megalodon jaws at the American Museum of Natural History, New York. (Photo credit: Wikipedia) Discovery Channel has come under fire from viewers and critics for its program, “Megalodon: The Monster Shark Lives,” which opened opened the network's “Shark Week”. The ratings were not the problem: Megalodon drew the highest dating for any [...] read »

snippet.title: The Real Evolution Debate: Is It All Just Natural Selection?
snippet.description: With all the attention given to the debate over evolution and creationism, you'd never know that a much more interesting debate has been going on for decades amongst evolutionary biologists: about the rivals to natural selection. read »

snippet.title: Ancient Footprints Throw Early Human Pre-History Into Turmoil
snippet.description: VideoThe discovery of 850,000-year-old muddy footprints on an English beach have thrown our understanding of early human pre-history into turmoil. The 49 prints, found in Happisburgh, Norfolk, are the earliest in Europe by half a million years. They raise questions about how and when humans spread from their ancestral home in [...] read »

snippet.title: Cindy Chao's Butterfly Brooch Added to Smithsonian Gem Hall
snippet.description: The Smithsonian Institute National Museum of Natural History will add to its celebrated gem collection with Masterpiece Royal Butterfly by jewelry artisan Cindy Chao. The brooch will be the first jewelry piece by a Taiwanese designer to be inducted into the institution’s permanent collection. read »

snippet.title: Neil deGrasse Tyson: Vegas Got Me Into Twitter
snippet.description: Photo credit: Wikipedia These days, astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson is quite simply the face of space science. To say that the director of New York's Hayden Planetarium at the American Museum of Natural History has developed a cult-like following is an understatement—geeks simply go gonzo in his presence. It's not just his undeniable [...] read »

snippet.title: London's Late-Night Museums
snippet.description: London is filled with museums of all types and one of the coolest ways to see them is after hours. read »

snippet.title: Why Wu-Tang Will Release Just One Copy Of Its Secret Album
snippet.description: Wu-Tang's aim is to use the album as a springboard for the reconsideration of music as art, hoping that the approach will help restore recorded music to a place alongside visual art--and change the music business in the process.

snippet.title: NYC's Planetarium to Become a 200-person Video Game
snippet.description: If you’ve been to the Rose Center for Earth and Space, a.k.a. the Planetarium in New York City’s American Museum of Natural History, you know just how impressive it is. (Really, really impressive.) But thanks to a group of independent game developers, Babycastles, it’s about to become even more awesome than that. read »
